thread.title: Surprise leaves Clawson open to speaker options
thread.title_full: Surprise leaves Clawson open to speaker options

title: Surprise leaves Clawson open to speaker options
text:
After surprise in U.S. House speaker vote, Rep. Curt Clawson considers the next move for GOP Bartholomew Sullivan 6:35 PM, Oct 8, 2015 29 mins ago Previous Next Scott McIntyre/Staff Curt Clawson addresses the crowd at his election party at the Hyatt Regency Coconut Point in Bonita Springs after officially winning the special election for Congressional District 19 Republican congressman on Tuesday April 22, 2014. Scott McIntyre Copyright 2014 Journal Media Group. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten, or redistributed. House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy of Calif. speaks during a new conference on Capitol Hill in Washington, Thursday, Oct. 8, 2015, after dropping out of the race to replace House Speaker John Boehner, who is stepping down and retiring from Congress at the end of the month. (AP Photo/Evan Vucci) Evan Vucci Copyright 2015 Journal Media Group. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten, or redistributed. House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy of Calif. walks out of nomination vote meeting after dropping out of the race to replace House Speaker John Boehner, Thursday, Oct. 8, 2015, on Capitol Hill in Washington. In a stunning move, McCarthy withdrew his candidacy for House speaker Thursday, throwing Congress' Republican leadership into chaos. (AP Photo/Evan Vucci) Evan Vucci Copyright 2015 Journal Media Group. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten, or redistributed. House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy of Calif. speaks to the media about his decision not to run for nomination for House Speaker replacing John Boehner, Thursday, Oct. 8, 2015, on Capitol Hill in Washington. In a stunning move, McCarthy withdrew his candidacy for House speaker Thursday, throwing Congress' Republican leadership into chaos. (AP Photo/Jacquelyn Martin) Jacquelyn Martin Copyright 2015 Journal Media Group. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten, or redistributed. Show Caption Next 
WASHINGTON — It was over in just minutes and almost no one saw it coming. 
“Everyone was eating barbecue and McCarthy dropped the bomb,” said U.S. Rep. Curt Clawson, R-Bonita Springs. “I don’t think anybody saw it coming.” 
That would be Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy of California, thought to be the most likely prospect to succeed outgoing House Speaker John Boehner. Instead, McCarthy told the 247-member House Republican Conference he was bowing out of the Speaker’s race, explaining later, “I just think it’s best to have a new face.” 
Clawson, a member of the 40-member Freedom Caucus whose endorsement of fellow Floridian and former Florida House Speaker Daniel Webster prevented McCarthy from reaching the 218 votes he’d have needed to win, said the race is now “impossible to predict…because I don’t know who’s considering jumping in.” 
McCarthy had been challenged both by Webster and Jason Chaffetz of Utah. On Thursday, there was much speculation about drafting Wisconsin Congressman and former vice presidential nominee Paul Ryan for the job. No date for a conference election has been set. 
Asked if his party’s inability to hold a leadership election suggested that the caucus is ungovernable, Clawson gave his trademark outsider’s reply. 
“I personally think that the ambiguity of the current situation is OK, and that it’s an opportunity for improvement,” he said. “I view this whole process as an opportunity for improvement and an opportunity for a different leadership style which, I think, could help the whole nation. 
“The market and the voters are crying out for outsiders and folks with a different skill set,” he said. 
While the Freedom Caucus has endorsed Webster, Clawson said he is obligated “as the race opens up” to consider other candidates. Asked if he’d support McCarthy if he decided to stay on as majority leader and Steve Scalise of Louisiana stayed as whip, Clawson said he had respect for McCarthy putting “the team” ahead of his own ambitions. 
But he said he would not speculate on the other chairs in the leadership. 
“It’s too early till we have the top guy figured out and he should have a chance to influence the assembly of his own team, as in any sport or business,” he said. 
Clawson said he doesn’t see the leadership uncertainty as a distraction from the important and required work before the Congress as a series of deadlines for extending the debt ceiling and keeping the government operating loom. 
“People know how to do their jobs,” he said. Copyright 2015 Journal Media Group. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten, or redistributed.
